Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Shay Mavis at (269) 243-2725.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff member throws youth on the wall. Two weeks ago, a youth
did not want to take their medication, and the staff member
roughly forced the youth into a chair and grabbed the youth's arm.
Another staff member witnessed the incident. The youth had
bruises on their arms, hand, and leg from the incident. Another
staff member throws youth on the ground and sits on them
(investigated in 2025SIC0000355). A month ago, this staff
member pushed a youth through the door, causing the youth to hit
the door handle which resulted in a bruise.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on April 18, 2025,
and reported they had no additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on April
25, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth A
described being in school having a rough day, “opening lockers
and being disrespectful.” Youth A stated she was trying to leave
the school from the left hallway of the pod by pushing through
Staff 4 when Staff 1 grabbed her arm and pushed her outside
through the school door. Youth A reported the door handle was
broken, scraped Youth A’s left hip and left a bruise. Youth A
reported Staff 4 saw Staff 1 push Youth A out the door because
Staff 4 stayed outside to walk with Youth A. Youth A stated she
showed Staff 4 and Supervisor 3 the bruise. Youth A denied
receiving any medical attention and stated she did not believe she
needed any because it was only a bruise. Youth A stated she had
“no idea when this occurred.” Youth A reported she believes there
may have been snow on the ground. Youth A stated she believed
Youth B was the only other youth to see Staff 1 push Youth A
outside.
2

Youth A described Youth B having a rough day at the house about
one to two months ago, throwing stuff around the house and
refusing to take her medication. Youth A stated Supervisor 1
pushed Youth B into a chair in the living room. Youth A described
Youth B moved around the living room when Supervisor 1, who
was standing in front of Youth B, grabbed both of Youth B’s upper
arms and shoved Youth B down into a chair. Youth A reported
being down the hallway where the bedrooms are located when
this occurred. Youth A stated Youth B had two bruises on her
upper arms and one on her leg. Youth A described Staff 2, Staff 3
and another staff member (she could not recall who) witnessed
Supervisor 1 shove Youth B. Youth A stated Youth B talked with
Supervisor 3 and Director of Residential about the incident.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on April
25, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth B
described months ago, she was outside on the swing when
Supervisor 1 told her she needed to go back inside, or he would
put his hands on her, but he did not want to. Youth B stated
Supervisor 1 grabbed her by her arm, leaving a handprint for “two
months” and escorted her into the house. Youth B denied the
bruise still being on her arm. Youth B reported Supervisor 2 was
on the porch and saw Supervisor 1 grab Youth B’s arm. Youth B
stated when she got inside, Supervisor 1 told her to sit down and
take her allergy medication. Youth B described laying down on the
chairs, then laying down on the ground, then standing up and
walking around the living room. Youth B reported she was
“moving around a lot” so Supervisor 1 grabbed her hands and
tried to push her down into a chair. Youth B stated Youth A
witnessed Supervisor 1 trying to push Youth B into a chair.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 25,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 stated he did
not recall any incident with Youth A at the school. Staff 1 denied
ever pushing Youth A or any youth into a door or outside from the
school. Staff 1 reported he could not recall if there was a door
handle broke at the school.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 25,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 2 described
Youth B being upset at the house, flipping over chairs and tables.
Staff 2 reported Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 arrived at the
house to assist and asked Youth B to sit at the table and take her
medication. Staff 2 stated Youth B went outside and Supervisor 1
and Staff 3 followed Youth B. Staff 2 described Youth B coming
back into the house and being asked again to sit at the table.
3

Staff 2 reported Supervisor 1 moved a chair and asked Youth B to
sit in the chair. Staff 2 denied seeing Supervisor 1 push Youth B
down into the chair or ever place his hands on Youth B. Staff 2
reported Youth B eventually sat down in the chair on her own and
took her medication. Staff 2 stated she did not see any bruises on
Youth B. Staff 2 denied Youth B reporting she was injured or had
bruises.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
May 7, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Supervisor 2
described being on-call and arriving at the house with Supervisor
1 to assist because Youth B was throwing chairs in the house and
refusing to take her medication. Supervisor 2 reported Youth B
eventually sat down by herself but ended up walking outside to sit
on the swing. Supervisor 2 stated she and Supervisor 1 followed
Youth B outside and asked Youth B to return inside. Supervisor 2
described Supervisor 1 escorting Youth B back inside by holding
Youth B’s arm with one hand and walking with Youth B back into
the house. Supervisor 2 denied seeing Supervisor 1 grab or
squeeze Youth B’s arm. Supervisor 2 denied seeing Youth B get
tangled in the swings or pulled off the swing by Supervisor 1.
Supervisor 2 reported Youth B never said she was hurt or had a
bruise. Supervisor 2 denied seeing any bruises on Youth B.
Supervisor 2 stated when Youth B came back into the house she
eventually sat down and took her medication. Supervisor 2
denied seeing Supervisor 1 push Youth B down into a chair.
Supervisor 2 denied having any concerns with how Supervisor 1
interacted with Youth B outside or inside the house.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 7,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 3 described
Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 coming to assist because Youth B
was upset and refusing to take her medication. Staff 3 reported
Youth B went outside and sat in a swing. Staff 3 stated she was
sitting on the front porch and could see everything. Staff 3
described Supervisor 1 coming outside, talking with Youth B, then
escorting Youth B into the house. Staff 3 described the escort
being “per-policy” with Supervisor 1 having his hand on Youth B’s
arm guiding Youth B inside. Staff 3 reported she did not have any
concern with the escort and Youth B never said Supervisor 1 was
hurting her. Staff 3 denied ever seeing Supervisor 1 pull Youth B
from the swing. Staff 3 stated once Youth B entered the house,
she threw a table, chair, laid down on the ground and eventually
got up and sat down on her own accord and took her medication.
Staff 3 denied seeing Supervisor 1 push Youth B down into a
4

chair. Staff 3 reported weeks after the incident Youth B told her
she had bruise on her leg from the swing incident. Staff 3 stated
she saw the whole swing incident and did not believe the bruise
could have come from the swings.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
May 7, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Supervisor 1
described responding to the house for assistance due to Youth B
refusing to take her medication. Supervisor 1 stated he arrived at
the house with Supervisor 2. Supervisor 1 reported Youth B
walked out of the house to the swings, and he escorted her back
into the house. Supervisor 1 stated Supervisor 2 came outside
with him to talk with Youth B. Supervisor 1 described escorting
Youth B back into the house by touching the back of Youth B’s
arm and guiding her into the house. Supervisor 1 denied grabbing
or squeezing Youth B’s arm. Supervisor 1 denied there being any
struggle by the swing or Youth B getting tangled in the swing.
Supervisor 1 described Youth B entered the house and threw
chairs and pushed the table around. Supervisor 1 reported Youth
B eventually calmed down, sat down in a chair on her own accord
and took her medication. Supervisor denied pushing Youth B
down into a chair or touching Youth B. Supervisor 1 stated
Supervisor 2 and either Staff 2 or Staff 3 were working at the
house when these incidents occurred. Supervisor 1 reported he
did not believe any youth witnessed the incidents because it was
bedtime.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on May 7, 2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 4 described recalling an
incident months ago when Youth A was upset, slamming lockers,
screaming and walking out of the school. Staff 4 reported she
followed Youth A out of the school and walked with Youth A until
she calmed down and returned to school. Staff 4 denied seeing
Staff 1 push Youth A at any time. Staff 4 stated Youth A never
said anything to her about a bruise or her hip hurting.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s Health Care Visit record dated 4/18/25. Record
documents, “Youth called to nursing office to check for
reported bruising. Upon arrival youth stated that they had
already healed. Bruising was reported to have been on her
Lt lateral chest. Youth did raise her T-shirt up to show area
with no bruising present. Female staff were present.”
(Note: Youth A indicated in her interview on 4/25/25 with
5

Consultant and DHHS Worker, the bruise was on her left
hip.)
• Youth B’s Health Care Visit record dated 4/18/25. Record
documents, “Youth called to nursing office to check for
reported bruising. Upon arrival youth stated that they had
already healed and were not present. Bruising was
reported to have been on her Lt lower arm and Rt inner leg
proximal to her knee. Female staff were present.”
• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 1 completed the required Aegis training on
10/17/2024.
• Supervisor 1’s personnel file. There was one disciplinary
action form dated 07/09/23 not related to interactions with
youth. Supervisor completed the required Aegis training on
12/12/24, NEO training on orientation/policies on 06/08/22
and Culture of Care training on 6/05/24.
• Eagle Village Staff Code of Conduct Policy. Policy
documents, “At all times, staff shall treat residents and
coworkers with respect and dignity in words and actions. All
staff will strive to be professional in behavior, conversation
and all interactions with others.”
• Eagle Village Behavior Plans Policy documents, “It is Eagle
Village policy that physical abuse is never accepted in any
manner as an interaction between staff and clients.
Examples of physical abuse could be, but are not limited to:
paddling, spanking, hitting, slapping, kicking, hair pulling,
throwing, severe shaking, inappropriate touching with an
object, or an inappropriate therapeutic hold.”
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per staff interviews, Staff 1
did not push Youth A into a door and outside of the school and
Supervisor 1 did not grab Youth B’s arm or push her down into a
chair. Staff who were working and witnessed the events did not
describe the events as the allegations were listed or as Youth A
and Youth B described.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
6

Allegation On 4/23/25, a youth was self-harming with a piece of metal that
they found. A staff member was allegedly present and did not
intervene. The staff member told the youth to stop, but did not
physically intervene.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on April
25, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth A was
observed with cuts on both of her arms. Youth A described the
cuts being from self-harming. Youth A reported she found glass in
front of the house and used it to cut herself. Youth A stated youth
at the house break the windows and staff just leave the glass.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on April
25, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth B
described cutting herself for 20 minutes with a piece of metal she
found outside by the swings on 4/23/25 in front of Staff 2 and Staff
5. Youth B reported she was sitting in her bedroom, cutting her
wrists and legs while Staff 2 and Staff 5 watched. Youth B denied
Staff 2 or Staff 5 tried to physically stop her, and stated they only
verbally asked her to stop cutting. Youth B described Staff 2 being
in Youth B’s bedroom with her, while Staff 5 stood in the hallway.
Youth B denied any youth seeing her self-harm. Youth B stated
she believes another staff member may have been in the hall but
could not recall. Youth B reported she left her bedroom and gave
Supervisor 3 the piece of metal and got cleaned up. Youth B
stated her arms were bleeding so Supervisor 3 used hydrogen
peroxide on the cuts and bandaged her arm.
Director of Residential was interviewed face to face at the
facility on April 25, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker.
Director of Residential denied hearing anything about staff not
supervising or intervening when Youth B attempts to self-harm.
Director of Residential checked what staff were working 4/23/25
and reported Staff 2 was working but not Staff 5. Director of
Residential reported when youth break windows, the windows are
boarded up until they can be replaced, and shop vacs are used to
clean up the broken glass outside and inside. Director of
Residential stated staff do the best they can to pick up all the tiny
pieces of glass shards.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 25,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 2 described
working on 4/23/25. Staff 2 denied seeing Youth B self-harm and
only saw Supervisor 3 treat Youth B’s cuts. Staff 2 denied being
in Youth B’s room and watching Youth B self-harm. Staff 2 stated
staff would always intervene to stop a youth if they were cutting
themselves.
7

Supervisor 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
May 7, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Supervisor 3
described Youth B approaching her in the kitchen or living room
and saying she had self-harmed the evening of 4/23/25.
Supervisor 3 reported Youth B gave her the item she self-harmed
with and showed Supervisor 3 the cuts on her wrist. Supervisor 3
stated the cuts were not very deep, so she cleaned the cuts and
notified on-call. Supervisor 3 described staff will treat minor cuts
with hydrogen peroxide, soap and water and Neosporin.
Supervisor 3 reported she believes Youth B used a small piece of
glass found outside but it may have been something else.
Supervisor 3 stated Youth B will use her fingernail to self-harm or
the metal piece from a pencil. Supervisor 3 denied staff being
aware of Youth B cutting and not intervening. Supervisor 3
reported she could not recall which staff were working the evening
Youth B gave her the small piece of glass. Supervisor 3 denied
Youth B telling her staff watched her self-harm for 20 minutes and
not intervene. Supervisor 3 stated she recalled staff, could not
recall who, sitting outside Youth B’s room talking with Youth B as
Youth B was looking through a book.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report for Youth B dated 4/23/25. The report
documents Youth A handed Supervisor 3 a small piece of
metal stating she self-harmed on her legs and arms. Youth
B had three cuts on her wrist, Supervisor 3 administered
first aid, and the on-call therapist and on-call supervisor
were contacted. Youth B refused to talk with the on-call
therapist. There was nothing documented in the incident
report that staff did not intervene.
• Youth B’s safety plan and addendum dated 5/1/25. Entry
from addendum documents, “4/23/2025- [Youth B] self-
harmed again and debriefed with [Supervisor 3]. She was
placed back on close obs.” Youth B was not on close
observation on 4/23/25, prior to the incident.
• Staff 2’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 2 completed New Employee Orientation training
covering youth self-harming and supervision on 07/12/24.
• Eagle Village Therapeutic Holds Policy. Policy documents,
“When staff have attempted to help the youth de-escalate
without the success of the youth returning to a safe and
regulated state; the use of a Therapeutic Hold may become
necessary to keep the youth safe. The only approved
therapeutic hold techniques are the methods and
techniques taught in the required Aegis course and should
8

only be used when a resident is a serious threat of safety or
violence to self or others and/or after all verbal de-
escalation and behavior support techniques have been
exhausted.”
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per staff interviews and
documentation, there is no information to support Youth B was
self-harming in front of any staff without staff intervening.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4132 Grievance procedures.
Section (2) The procedure shall provide for all of the following:
Description (b) Addressing matters that relate to compliance with the act,
rules promulgated under the act, and the agency's written policies
and procedures regarding services covered by these rules.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility failed to address a youth's grievance.
Investigation Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on April
25, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth B stated
she completed two grievances and gave them to Director of
Residential regarding the incident by the swings with Supervisor 1.
Youth B reported no one ever talked to her about the grievances
she filed.
Director of Residential was interviewed face to face at the
facility on April 25, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker
and on May 21, 2025, with just me. Director of Residential
reported she does not have any documentation of any grievances
or requests for follow-up from Youth B.
Clinical Services Manager was interviewed via telephone on
May 16, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Clinical
Services Manager described being Youth B’s mentor. Clinical
Services Manager reported Youth B called her the night of the
incident with Supervisor 1 and stated she was going to file a
grievance regarding the incident and interaction with Supervisor 1.
Clinical Services Manager stated the following day, Youth B gave
her a completed grievance form and Clinical Services Manager
gave the grievance form to Supervisor 3. Clinical Services
Manager reported the form should have then been delivered to
Director of Residential to log and address the grievance.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
May 21, 2025. Supervisor 3 stated she did not recall ever
receiving a grievance form from Youth B or Clinical Services
9

Manager. Supervisor 3 reported she remembered talking with
Youth B about the event with Supervisor 1 but did not recall Youth
B completing a grievance form.
Documents Reviewed:
• Eagle Village Grievance Procedure for Residents and/or
Parents Policy. The policy documents, “All grievance
documentation is collected and stored in a binder in which
the Director of Residential Services keeps. The Residential
Treatment Supervisor will meet with or schedule an
appointment with the grievant (by phone if a parent/worker),
to discuss the nature of the concern within 7 days. If it is
determined that resolution could be handled by the
Residential Treatment Supervisor or Family Therapist, the
Director of Residential Services is simply notified of the
grievance and the form/written document, detailing the
issue and resolution, is forwarded to the Director of
Residential Services. If a resolution cannot be managed,
the Director of Residential Services meets with the grievant
(by phone if a parent of worker) to further discuss and
resolve the matter within 7 days.”
• Supervisor 3’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary
record and Supervisor 3 completed Academy – Rule Book
training on 4/30/2025 and New Hire Orientation training on
4/17/2024.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as per Youth B and Clinical
Services Manager interviews, Youth B completed a grievance
form, gave the grievance form to Clinical Services Manager and
Clinical Services Manager gave the grievance form to Supervisor
3. The grievance form cannot be located by the facility and was
not logged as ever being completed and turned in by Youth B.
Conclusion Violation Established
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
